definition: Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏子, hero of book 晏子春秋
surname Yan
late/quiet

sentences.english: Thus Yan Ying was able to remove three potential threats to the country of Qi without lifting a finger.
sentences.chinese: 于是晏婴不费吹灰之力就铲除了齐国的三个隐患。

definition: Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏婴, hero of book 晏子春秋
Lord Menchang of Qi, Chancellor of Qi and of Wei during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Guan Zhong (-645 BC), famous politician of Qi 齊國|齐国 of Spring and Autumn period/known as Guangzi 管子
a restricted view through a bamboo tube
Ling Xiangru (dates unknown, 3rd century BC), famous statesman of Zhao 趙國|赵国
Lu, vassal state at the time of the Zhou Dynasty 周朝|周朝[Zhou1 chao2], located in the southwest of present-day Shandong 山東|山东[Shan1 dong1], birthplace of Confucius
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
King Xuan of Qi (reigned 342-324 BC)
the lord of Lu (who declined to employ Confucius)
Zi Chan (?-522 BC), statesman and philosopher during the Spring and Autumn period
Zi Gong or Duanmu Ci 端木賜|端木赐[Duan1 mu4 Ci4] (520 BC-), disciple of Confucius
Su Qin (340-284 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)

Sima Rangju (c. 800 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), military strategist of the Qi State 齊國|齐国[Qi2 guo2] and author of “Methods of Sima” 司馬法|司马法[Si1 ma3 Fa3], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]

Qi state of Western Zhou and the Warring states (1122-265 BC), centered in Shandong
